Dec 19, 2016

Datasets Digest: sea level change trends | HackerNews most popular stories | U.S. worker fatalities

Today, we’re rounding out your week with three newly created datasets on some hot and interesting topics. Check these out to learn the current state of affairs in climate change, HackerNews, and occupational hazards. Enjoy!

Sea Level Change Trends

via @noaa

Watch out, Louisianna! Per 30+ years of Main Sea Level trend data from the Center for Operational Oceanographic Products and Services (CO-OPS), Eugene Island and Grand Isle, where “every day is an adventure,” are the two spots with the highest trending increases in sea level at +9.65 mm/yr. and +9.05 mm/yr., respectively. On the flipside, Alaska claims the top two sea level decreases nationwide, with Skagway at -17.59 mm/yr. and Yakutat at -14.1 mm/yr.

See U.S. sea level data by location

HackerNews Most Popular Stories

via @thule179

What can we learn by looking at how many points different HackerNews stories have? For starters, “Steve Jobs has passed away.” (4271 points) was a more popular story than “UK votes to leave EU” (3125 points) amongst the HackerNews crowd. @thule179 has compiled this set of about 400 stories with more than 100 points on Hacker News using the HN Search API, and included several data visualizations of points and comments by story creation time.

Explore the data

U.S. reported worker fatalities

via @awram

“Worker killed after being engulfed by mulch.” This is just one of the many occupational hazards described in detail in this dataset, which provides summaries of work-related fatalities reported to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) over the past two years. What conclusions can you draw from analyzing this data? Will you take extra precautions with mulch next time you’re gardening? @awram is seeking contributors for this project, so if you have insights or more data to share on this topic, let him know by requesting to be a contributor!

Collaborate on this dataset

MEDIA HIGHLIGHT

This week, the Department of Defense’ Defense Digital Service (DDS) launched their new open data portal, data.mil. DDS is partnering with data.world by publishing newly-released defense data on their data.world organization page.

Read more about it in Fedscoop
